title: Change Router#match() signature
body: from `(req[, i])` to `(method, url[, i])`, make it public

title: Sequential coupling in route/middleware initialization
Use os.platform to determine End-of-line
body: This patch adds a check to see if os.platform is available. If so, it will be used to determine end-of-line, otherwise it will default to \r\n as it is the default for 2.5.2.

title: Remove 'app' argument to creating a new router
body:
If the app is not required for Router creation, then users can create disjoint routes and use them at different times in the middleware chain. It could also aid in more dynamic route creation disjoint from knowing the app.

Currently the 'app' parameter is used only to detect strict and case sensitive routes which could instead be arguments to the router creation.

title: Screencasts @gh-pages
body:
The source code for your screencasts should add type="application/x-shockwave-flash" on the embed tags. These videos do not work in my environment, Chrome stable on Ubuntu 11.10 amd64, without adding that attribute.

Basically transform:
embed src="http://screenr.com/Content/assets/screenr_1116090935.swf" flashvars="i=139583" allowfullscreen="true" width="560" height="345" pluginspage="http://www.macromedia.com/go/getflashplayer"

To something like:
embed type="application/x-shockwave-flash" src="http://screenr.com/Content/assets/screenr_1116090935.swf" flashvars="i=139583" allowfullscreen="true" width="560" height="345" pluginspage="http://www.macromedia.com/go/getflashplayer"

Thank you!

title: EOL style per platform
body:
I made a change to select the end-of-line code depending on the platform type.
The patch also fixed the typo of '\n' in the session support string and package.json, which was apparently fixed in the 2.x branch.
Thank you.

title: extensions section on the site
body: for the regulars express-param, express-resource, http://railwayjs.com/routing.html, etc

title: higher-level framework section on site
body: for things like http://railwayjs.com/

title: consider removing app.configure()
body:
pros:
- you can use `app.settings.env`
- less misleading since people often think it's required
- middleware config in separate function calls is difficult to manage
- it's unclear that the functions are executed immediately

cons:
- uglier
- less declarative

todo:
- add it to list of changes
- update examples
- remove internal use of .configure()

title: Request to bump connect requirement for 2.x
body: As of `2.5.2`, the connect requirement is set to `1.8.x`. This was fine until connect `1.8.2` introduced a breaking API change for file uploads. I would like the connection version to be set to `~1.8.2` for the `2.x` branch, since using express I cannot really control if the installed connect is pre- or post-1.8.2.

title: update keywords for search.npmjs.org
body:
Apparently, search.npmjs.org uses keywords to index their modules.

Now, searching for `express`, express didn't show up. We can fix this temporary by adding the `express` keyword. Or, we can hope that search.npmjs.org gets a better search backend.

title: more methods for parameterized header fields
body: similar to res.cache()

can you see the SexMe in the id - is this random or intended

title: add consolidate.js dep
body: consider this for 3x, it would make things a lot easier for people, and we can maintain template engine support within consolidate.js

title: Redirect should respect X-Forwarded-Proto header
Add express-negotiate to 3rd party module list
body: I just released a expressjs extension to allow cleaner content negotiation (based on the accept header or on a file extension).  If you'd like to add it to the 3rd party module list, here's a patch.

title: Setting content type to rss+xml serves up octet-stream
body:
Calling `res.contentType('application/rss+xml')` will send the content type as application/octet-stream.

Calling `res.contentType('rss')` works fine.

Just a bit confusing, eh?

title: expose Router
body: in such a way that you can use several if you like (useful for higher level frameworks etc)

title: res.redirect() relative / absolute
body:
relative: `res.redirect('user/login')`  -> `GET /blog/user/login` etc
absolute: `res.redirect('/user/login')` -> `GET /user/login` etc

Should this behavior be an error or an graceful warning ? Why this change was introduced now ?

Thanks.

title: exposing express session storage?
body:
Hey guys, 

I am currently following this guide to allow socket.io to read express session storage: http://www.danielbaulig.de/socket-ioexpress/

Basically, I am using express.session.MemoryStore for session memory, and exposing that in a global variable that i can refer to in other places such as socket.io (for authentication)

However, the problem arise when i try to run the app in NODE_ENV=production, the app gives me the following warning:

Warning: connection.session() MemoryStore is not
designed for a production environment, as it will leak
memory, and obviously only work within a single process.

Anyone have any idea of how to properly resolve this?

Thanks a lot :)

Jason

The same is for JS and CSS files. I can't find a way to make Express use these files (render('index') will render 'index.ejs' in development but 'index.min.ejs' in production mode)

title: Reminder for users using the examples
body:
Just a comment reminder. Already had to answer two stack overflow questions with users of the same problem.

Since version 2.0 of connect now includes formidable and parses all requests, users have been having issues with formidable on their own.

title: next()ing an error with json content type wont return formatted error
body:
jQuery
    $.ajax({url:"http://localhost:3000/nodeapi/error", dataType:'json'})

Express
    app.get('/error', function(req, res, next) {
        next(new Error('my custom error'))
    })

Will produce
    {"error":{}}

In development mode only.

It appears the line 78 of errorHandler.js does the following.

```
var json = JSON.stringify({ error: err });
```

Try the following in a browser to see the same problem
    JSON.stringify(new Error('test'))

Cheers,

Tim

title: require('json') not working in express
body:
node.js provides the infrastructure to load json file using require.

In node.js the following works:

`var items = require('items')`

and `items` will contain the parsed json content of the file `items.json`

But when doing the same in express, I get:

500 Error: Cannot find module 'items'
at Function._resolveFilename (module.js:317:11)
at Function._load (module.js:262:25)
at require (module.js:346:19)
at /home/gabriel/app/routes/index.js:21:15
at callbacks (/home/gabriel/.node_libraries/.npm/express/2.5.1/package/lib/router/index.js:272:11)
at param (/home/gabriel/.node_libraries/.npm/express/2.5.1/package/lib/router/index.js:246:11)
at pass (/home/gabriel/.node_libraries/.npm/express/2.5.1/package/lib/router/index.js:253:5)

Is this the desired behavior? Am I getting something wrong?

Thanks!

title: Client Javascript and stylesheet injection issues
body:
I am trying to write my first Express app. I am using the vanilla Express install with Jade and Stylus. Node v0.4.11, Express 2.5.0, Jade 0.18.0, 0.19.3. I am switching layouts for part of the app. I'm using the following route to switch layouts: `exports.login = function(req, res) { res.render('login', { layout: 'auth_layout.jade', title : 'Login' }); };` And in this layout, I have a number of css and javascript links/scripts: `link(rel='stylesheet', href='/stylesheets/reset.css') link(rel='stylesheet', href='/stylesheets/text.css') link(rel='stylesheet', href='/stylesheets/960.css') link(rel='stylesheet', href='/stylesheets/validationEngine.jquery.css') link(rel='stylesheet', href='/stylesheets/main.css') link(rel='stylesheet', href='/stylesheets/login.css') script(type='text/javascript',src='http://ajax.googleapis.com/ajax/libs/jquery/1.7.0/jquery.min.js') script(type='text/javascript',src='/javascripts/jquery.validationEngine.js') script(type='text/javascript',src='/javascripts/login.js')` Note that one of the css files linked in is login.css. And, the last javascript file is login.js. When these files are rendered into the browser, their contents are injected with the contents of the dom for the app: ` Login
  • Home
  • Pricing
  • Docs
  • Support
  • Jobs
  • Blog
  • Signup
  • Login
 
Username:
Password:
  Remember Me?

Forgot your password? Recover it here.
Or sign in with:
Help spread the word about
Support  | Terms & Conditions  | Privacy Policy
© 2011, ABC, Inc.
 
` It appears that Express or Stylus is injecting the dom into files with the same name as the Jade route file. If I name/rename the files and links something else, this problem doesn't occur.

title: app.address() crashes in HTTP + HTTPS mode
body:
I'm trying to run both HTTP and HTTPS servers as described in [this gist](https://gist.github.com/1051583).

It all runs fine until it hits the last auto-generated `console.log` which invokes `app.address().port`, throwing the following error:

```
TypeError: Bad file descriptor argument
    at HTTPServer.address (net.js:1129:10)
    at Object.<anonymous> (/Users/mtam/test/app.js:52:67)
    at Module._compile (module.js:411:26)
    at Object..js (module.js:417:10)
    at Module.load (module.js:343:31)
    at Function._load (module.js:302:12)
    at Array.<anonymous> (module.js:430:10)
    at EventEmitter._tickCallback (node.js:126:26)
```

The servers run perfectly if I remove that line.

A couple things:
1. Is `app.address()` documented somewhere?
2. What's a good way to check if an incoming request is HTTP or HTTPS? I wanted to use `app.address().port`, but that crashed; I see some HTTPS-specific variables in `req`, but depending on that seems unreliable.

Thanks!

title: TypeError: Object function createApplication() has no method 'createServer'
body:
Stack trace:

```
01:45:50 web.1     | TypeError: Object function createApplication() {
01:45:50 web.1     |   var app = connect();
01:45:50 web.1     |   utils.merge(app, proto);
01:45:50 web.1     |   app.request = { __proto__: req };
01:45:50 web.1     |   app.response = { __proto__: res };
01:45:50 web.1     |   app.init();
01:45:50 web.1     |   return app;
01:45:50 web.1     | } has no method 'createServer'
```

Using Node.js 0.6.0, npm from git, express from git.

```
express@3.0.0alpha1-pre ./node_modules/express 
├── commander@0.3.2
├── mime@1.2.4
├── mkdirp@0.0.7
├── qs@0.3.2
└── connect@2.0.0alpha1
```

Happens on:

```
Express    = require "express"
Express.createServer()
```

title: refine route lookup mechanisms
body: the current app.lookup.get() etc stuff is kinda more "cute" than anything else, perhaps just a simple app.routes.filter(fn) and that's it

title: mounting + cookies / redirect tests
body: a blog mounted at `/blog` on an app mounted at `/store` should default cookie paths, redirects etc to `/store/blog` etc

title: Update examples
body: yup

title: signed cookie tests
body: signed json cookies as well

title: change view signature to accept filename
body:
currently: `engine.render(str, [options, ] callback)`
proposed: `engine.render(filename, [options, ] callback)`

With this we can also remove the view cache option as express will
not be touching the files for lookup. This pushes more work on the
engine but ultimately a bit more flexibility for the engine as well.

Also since `.render()` is so common we should probably go with
something ugly like `engine.__render(filename...)`

We also have the choice of doing _some_ lookup, for example
allowing `index.<engine>` files so you can do `res.render('user')`
for _./views/user.jade_ or _./views/user/index.jade_,
or leave this entirely to the engine as well.

title: Compiler middleware doesn't works
body:
I run node v0.4.9 and express 2.5.0, in my app.coffee file I have:     

app.use express.compiler { src: __dirname + '/pubic', enable: ['less', 'coffeescript'] }
app.use express.static __dirname + '/public'

And the directory structure for the is as follows

/public
    /scripts
        index.coffee
    /stylesheets
        index.less

 But when I request  scripts/index.js or  stylesheets/index.css, I get a 404 error.

title: History.md out of date
body: Please describe in History.md what has changed since 2.4.5.

title: Make express scaffolding generate cr/lf on Windows
body:
If you use Express on Windows you don't get CRLF. On Windows this is standard as several text editors expect it like notepad.

In Windows it would be nice if Express could add the CRLF.

title: minor fix in the guide
body: I found a part of the guide that doesn't seem clear; there's a section that says "Express also provides the view options setting..." and explains the 'view options' option, then it tells about the layout: option for render, then it lists various ways you can set the layout, and then it says "A good example of this is specifying custom ejs opening and closing tags". At this point "this" sounds as if it refers to the layout option, while it really refers to the 'view options' setting which was mentioned about one page earlier.

title: Express depends on commander@0.0.4, which does not support node.js 5
Cannot detect invalid JSON in bodyParser
body:
I'm trying to return a non-500 error + message when someone POSTs invalid JSON, but I can't seem to capture this error, even with my own overridden express.bodyParser.parse.

It appears that `JSON.parse` doesn't throw any exceptions as I would expect, and thus doesn't next() any errors because as far as it's concerned there are none. :/

The invalid JSON is only reported later when the data is passed to `methodOverride`:

```
TypeError: Cannot use 'in' operator to search for '_method' in {ThisIsNotValidJson
    at String.IN (native)
    at Object.methodOverride [as handle] (/Users/secoif/Projects/.../node_modules/express/node_modules/connect/lib/middleware/methodOverride.js:27:31)
    at next (/Users/secoif/Projects/.../node_modules/express/node_modules/connect/lib/http.js:201:15)
    at Object.cookieParser [as handle] (/Users/secoif/Projects/.../node_modules/express/node_modules/connect/lib/middleware/cookieParser.js:44:5)
    at next (/Users/secoif/Projects/.../node_modules/express/node_modules/connect/lib/http.js:201:15)
    at next (/Users/secoif/Projects/.../node_modules/express/node_modules/connect/lib/http.js:203:9)
    at IncomingMessage.<anonymous> (/Users/secoif/Projects/.../node_modules/express/node_modules/connect/lib/middleware/bodyParser.js:81:9)
    at IncomingMessage.emit (events.js:61:17)
    at HTTPParser.onMessageComplete (http.js:133:23)
    at Socket.ondata (http.js:1029:22)
```

Someone with the exact same issue here: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/7478917/catching-illegal-json-post-data-in-express

title: Dynamic helpers override route-specific locals... this is bad
body:
Dynamic helpers override route-specific locals... this is bad?  Maybe?

So... I might be a complete idiot, but I think dynamic helpers should NOT take precedence over route-specific locals (i.e. locals passed directly to `res.render()`.  As of right now, I believe this is the case... running Express 2.x or whatever is currently in npm.

I'm of the opinion that dynamic view helpers are to be used only when a view accesses a local var that would otherwise be unavailable...

Thoughts?

title: use any Commander version above 0.0.4
body:
The commander version is hardcoded to 0.0.4, and so even Express master supports Node 0.5.x or above the dependencies resolution fails.

I don't actually know if that was deliberate and this is the first patch that came to my mind, quick edited and not tested though.

title: HEAD Request - On 404
body:
if i send a head request on a 404 url, i have the node warning "This type of response MUST NOT have a body. Ignoring data passed to end()"

The context is :

$ npm install express jade
$ node_modules/express/bin/express .
destination is not empty, continue? y
...
$ node app.js
Express server listening on port 3000 in development mode
...

$ curl --head http://localhost:3000/
HTTP/1.1 200 OK
X-Powered-By: Express
Content-Type: text/html; charset=utf-8
Content-Length: 277
Connection: keep-alive
**==> everything is ok**

$ curl --head http://localhost:3000/foo
HTTP/1.1 404 Not Found
X-Powered-By: Express
Content-Type: text/plain
Connection: keep-alive
**==> curl response is ok but i have in console a node warning "This type of response MUST NOT have a body. Ignoring data passed to end()"**

title: *basic* express app broken in v0.5.10
body:
please fix

```
ryan@mac1234:/tmp% mkdir test
ryan@mac1234:/tmp% cd test
ryan@mac1234:/tmp/test% npm install express
express@1.0.7 ./node_modules/express 
├── qs@0.3.1
└── connect@1.0.1
ryan@mac1234:/tmp/test% cat > x.js  
var app = require('express').createServer();

app.get('/', function(req, res){
    res.send('Hello World');
});

app.listen(3000);
ryan@mac1234:/tmp/test% vim x.js 
ryan@mac1234:/tmp/test% node x.js 

node.js:202
        throw e; // process.nextTick error, or 'error' event on first tick
              ^
```

title: Express 3.0.0.alpha1, Connect 2.0.0alpha1 and Node.js 0.5.9 Windows .exe
express command-line not work under windows
response.js: If viewCallbacks is an empty array, then the render helper function in res.render will never be called.
body: I also removed the "done" variable, which wasn't being used. If that's wrong, let me know and I'll fix it. Cheers!

0.6 is immenent, 

Do we have any kind of rough ETA on when express 3.0 is "usable" other then "when it's done"

title: Added JSHTML template engine for cli helper :)
body:
JSHTML is a express compatible template engine 
with very nice syntax.

https://github.com/LuvDaSun/jshtml

title: app.match / app.lookup return Objects, not Functions
DUPLICATE: app.match / app.lookup return Objects, not Functions (see issue 862)
Html entity within data in http request corrupts data
move req.notify() into the express-messages extension
body: bit of a weird one to have in core. maybe rename express-messages as well

title: application/json responses fail for integer values
body:
I expect to be able to
- set the response content type to application/json
- call res.send with an integer value for the response body
- receive the integer value in the response body

the actual behavior is this exception:

```
TypeError: Argument must be a string
    at ServerResponse.send
```

Here is the failing example app: https://gist.github.com/1271167

using express version 2.2.0

title: JSONP striping cleaning Bracket
Express from npm repo won't install on stable node.js versions
body:
The current version of express.js requires node.js 0.5.0 or higher.

This prevents a new application being set up on a node.js installation from the 0.4 (stable) branch.

It seems not useful to require users to switch to the "unstable" branch on node.js to run express.js

title: Unable to install 2.4.6 on Node.js 0.4.12
body:
I am not able to install express 2.4.6 on Node.js 0.4.12. It tells me that there is an "unsupported" error, due to an incompatibility between Connect 2.0.0alpha1 and Node 0.4.x. Connect 2.0.0alpha1 requires Node.js 0.5.0 or above.

How can I install Express 2.4.6 anyway?

title: "connect": ">= 1.5.2 < 2.0.0" installs 2.0.0alpha
body:
It looks like a bug in npm. This prevents the installation express for systems that are not running node 0.5
Fix:

"connect": ">= 1.5.2 <  1.9.9"

title: Render with a callback problem
lib/https.js requires native https, but doesn't use it
body: [lib/https.js](https://github.com/visionmedia/express/blob/master/lib/https.js) requires native https (`https = require('https');`), but doesn't use it. Looks wrong.

title: Error: the "filename" option is required to use includes
Espresso + Mongoose + fs.readdir, breaks  app.error();
body:
Hi,
I found one "magic" bug.
Here is a source code for simulate it: https://github.com/zxcabs/express_expresso_mongoose_readdir

I can't understand what happened, but if i use _mongoose.connect()_ + _fs.readdir_ and run _expresso_ test, it's breaks express error handling. If i removed _mongoose.connect()_ or _fs.readdir_, and run test again, test end well.

And if I run the Express application, without any change of all is working well.

title: Incorrect paths constructed for index view lookup
body:
I am attempting to use the convenient index view lookup feature of express like so:

`res.render('my-view');`

(located in `/views/my-view/index.jade`)

**The view fails to load and I get the following error in the console:**

failed to locate view "my-view", tried:
- C:\Users\Wilson\Documents\Sites\express-site/views/my-view.jade
- C:\Users\Wilson\Documents\Sites\express-site/views/C:\Users\Wilson\Documents
  \Sites\express-site/views/my-view/index.jade
- C:\Users\Wilson\Documents\Sites\express-site/views/C:\Users\Wilson\Documents
  \Sites\express-site/views/../my-view/index.jade
- C:\Users\Wilson\Documents\Sites\express-site/views/C:\Users\Wilson\Documents
  \Sites\express-site/views/my-view.jade

**For the time being I am having to use the longer alternative:**

`res.render('my-view/index', {layout: '../layout'});`

title: Minor typos fixed in guide.md
body:
Very minor.  My playing with different markdown apps got me to read the spec enough to know how to fix "_req.body._method_" to "_req.body._method_" in order to get the embedded '_' to work with discount.

Check the mime 'type' <--> 'subtype' reversal.  I'm pretty sure I've got it right.  (section `req.is()` approx. line 685)

I'll have to check some stuff before next pull request and consult with you whether I'm right / wrong / _other_ ...

title: Exception after calling res.end causes busy loop
body:
Express routing goes to busy loop if end is called to a response and code throws exception

```
app.get('/test', function(req, res) {

    res.end();
    throw 'Some error';
});
```

Output

...
TypeError: Cannot call method 'destroy' of null
    at next (/Users/teemuikonen/node_modules/express/node_modules/connect/lib/http.js:162:47)
    at next (/Users/teemuikonen/node_modules/express/node_modules/connect/lib/http.js:150:23)

title: added utf-8 paths support
body:
Hello again.
I've looked through 'connect' sources, and found out that it correctly decodes the path for static resources.
I think the node.exe is the culprit now - it gets the correct path when calling "fs.stat" method, but fails to locate this path. Maybe because I'm on windows.

Another bug I've found in Express is that utf-8 routes don't work.
I've corrected it, by modifying the Router class.

title: Utf-8 url is unavailable
body:
Hello.
I've tried to map a Utf-8 url, or get a utf-8 named static resource, but it says that it can't find %D0%DA%D[something else].
I think, you should do decodeURIComponent on the path before searching for a mapping (or a file).
